content.description: This is the line that skirts the left side of the plaque without touching the plaque.  Ya might get a ticket if you touch it.  It starts a bit stiffer on smooth granite, then the low angle helps to make the upper part mellower.  It is kinda neat to check out this ancient plaque up close.
content.protection: A TR. You can use a #3 & #6 hex & an old bolt off to the left.
content.location: This is just left of the big plaque.

content.description:
Climb the crack that is in the small roof on the right side of the face. The crack turns into a large flake that you can ride to the easy friction slab above. 

 There is a sit start to this that starts in the hand crack at the back of the small roof.
content.location: Find the cool, small little roof with a hand crack on the right side of the face. That's the start.

content.description: Climb the weakness to the right of the bulge (Jaws) and to the left of the small roof (Watery). Gain the small, right-facing corner, and with tricky footwork, gain a slopey jug before the easy slab above.
content.location: This is on the right side of the Main Face between Jaws and Watery.

content.description: Climb the obvious inside corner. At the top, go to the right.
content.location: It is far right of the face at the inside corner.

content.description: Follow up the slab right of sea shell and up the slabby small groove right of the slabby arete
content.location: This is right of Sea Shell on the right side of the plaque. It is right of Waver.

content.description: Follow up the cracks to the top.
content.protection: A pad, gear, or a TR.
content.location: This follow up the obvious weakness between Waterproof and the Sea Urchin. It is on the right side of the plaque.

content.description:
Climb the bulge using good holds including a slot. The start of this route has different rock than the rest of the face, so you'll know you're in the right spot. Once your feet are with you up on the slab above the bulge, ascend the seemingly blank slab above on good friction. 

 A slabby friction cruxy move is about 15' off-the-deck, so be warned if you attempt to boulder/solo this one.
content.location: Find the bulge with different rock to the right of the plaque. Start on the good holds on the bulge.

content.description: This line follows straight up the crack on the right of the plaque until about ten fet up. Boston Rocks says to go around the bulge/roof at a 5.10, but you can go straight up and over with a key high left foot on the lip of the bulge and some super thin, slabby crimp (possibly where the 10+ comes in, in the book?). Follow it up to the top.
content.location: It is just right of the plaque. Follow up the crack to the obvious bulge/roof.

content.description: Follow up the slab just left of the crack. The crack is off. Move up just left of the small bulge/roof of Full Fathom Five. This section just before the topout is the crux.
content.location: It is just right of the plaque and Down to the Sea.

content.description: Start below the dark hole in the face, and get your hand in it. Move onto the face above the inside corner, and gain the upper slab via good holds. Tall folks will be able to sneak a foot over to the inside corner depending on how you do this.
content.location: Find the dark hole about the size of your fist about 10 feet to the left of the inside corner and 10 feet off the ground.

content.description: Start at the middle of the slab with some smears. Good slab technique will come in helpful, otherwise you better have a rope! Avoid trending left to the corner; however, it is an option if you need to escape.
content.location: This ascends the face to the right of the inside corner.

content.description: If you look closely enough...you can see ancient claw prints up the right side of the plaque.  Just kidding'.  This is the line just right of the plaque.  It goes at a nice, moderate grade.  The plaque is off-limits.  You can curl left above the plaque.
content.protection: A TR, it is a good ways back for an anchor.
content.location: It is just right of the large plaque. Do not touch the plaque.

content.description:
This is the main climbing area at Stage Fort Park. The crag has toprope problems on smooth rock.

 The GPS is not accurate, yet.

 To be edited in.
